thread.title: Why this market is stuck in a ‘nervous zone’
thread.title_full: Why this market is stuck in a ‘nervous zone’ - MarketWatch

author: Victor Reklaitis
title: Why this market is stuck in a ‘nervous zone’
text:
The scaredy-cats say the bear market has started , while the Pollyannas emphasize we’re not nearing recession, so stocks soon will scamper higher.
Or the middle ground between these two extremes might best describe this market.
It’s neither crash time nor rally time, according to S&P Capital IQ’s Sam Stovall. At his shop, they “aren’t looking for a bear market, just a deeper correction,” he said in a note late Wednesday.
In other words, it’s just a “nervous zone before any policy actions and the release of third-quarter earnings,” as Alan Gayle at Ridgeworth Investments has put it , according to a Wall Street Journal report.
The Federal Reserve “didn’t hike interest rates, but they did help elevate uncertainty and volatility,” Stovall said. “Going forward, we see the market trending lower to retest the August 25 closing low and possibly move even lower,” he added. The equity strategist said a “less-likely scenario” is “some backing and filling before moving higher,” but either way, his team at S&P Capital IQ feels “no sense of urgency to buy these near-term dips.”
Fed chief Janet Yellen could help the market get out of its awkward spot with a speech today at 5 p.m. Eastern Time. She “could give hints on how close the Fed is to the first rate hike,” writes Bill McBride over at the Calculated Risk blog . He points out inflation is still below the Fed’s target, and Yellen’s speech is titled “Inflation Dynamics and Monetary Policy” — “she addresses the key topic!”
Or Yellen simply might add to the uncertain mood, in which case it may not be until at least Oct. 8, when Alcoa AA, -3.16% kicks off the earnings season , that traders can hope to begin climbing out of that “nervous zone.” MarketWatch has warned that investors shouldn’t expect Yellen to offer clues on rate-hike timing .
While U.S. stocks and the Fed look to be stuck in a rut (the Fed “ needs to get unstuck ,” argues AEI’s Edward Pinto over at RealClearMarkets), the call of the day sees a bullish shift for hard-hit Chinese equities. On the other hand, today’s chart provides an unflattering view of China’s Shanghai Composite, with a touch of dark humor.
Key market gauges S&P futures ESZ5, -0.81% and Dow futures YMZ5, -0.86% are pointing to a lower open , and European stocks SXXP, -1.46% are also wrapped in red. Asian markets ADOW, -0.81% were mixed, with Japan led lower by car makers . Oil CLX5, -0.36% and gold GCZ5, +0.49% are higher, while the dollar DXY, -0.36% is lower.
Buzz Getty Images Nike is due to grab the spotlight after the close. Speaking of China, Boeing BA, -1.73% could make moves after news of its $38 billion deal was unveiled as Chinese President Xi Jinping visited Seattle.
Nike NKE, -0.47% , Pier 1 PIR, -0.67% and Bed Bath & Beyond BBBY, -0.38% are slated to post earnings after the close, while Accenture ACN, +0.19% and KB Home KBH, +1.47% are due to report before the open.
BMW BMW, -6.87% shares are plunging in European trading on emissions news that sounds Volkswagen-y. VOW3, -1.68% VLKAY, +6.53%
Towers Watson’s TW, +2.09% CEO timed his recent massive stock sale quite well.
